Still, the fear was very real at the time. Be prepared that you may feel it, too, no matter what you choose.) It is worth noting that my best friend lives in a country where healthcare is not dependent upon landing a good job. She simply could not comprehend the urgency I felt on that score.So, I turned to my father, who is very wise and very tender. He also has always known how to speak in a way my brain will hear through my anxiety. I am INCREDIBLY lucky. I called him and expressed all my fears about what I would do and how I thought I had set myself up for failure by foolishly choosing to study what I loved, rather than something practical.My software engineer, highly-educated father then told me how jealous he was of me. Of what I knew. He told me that there would come a time when the knowledge he had accrued would simply no longer be useful. He would not be a software engineer forever. And once he was no longer working, his skills would see far less use, and be far less applicable in day to day life. He wasn't sorry for choosing to study what he loved, but he was aware that there would, eventually, come a time that it was no longer necessary or useful.He reminded me that I would never see that day. That what I learned‚Äîwhether it was communication skills or writing skills or how to cogently present and defend an opinion or how to process lots of data into a conclusion or how to interpret information in myriad ways or even what I had learned about humanity through studying their art (both the fictions and truths they told in that art) ‚Äîwould NEVER be useless. My education would serve me in both my vocation, whatever it may be, and my life. My father told me how wonderful he thought that was. My fears didn't go away, but they quieted enough for me to see possibilities and futures that the tunnel vision of fear had obscured.When you study English, you study so much more than stories. In order to understand the symbolism, you have to study culture, law, science, philosophy, religion, history, etc. As you study these other things, even just the small slices of them that allow you to understand, you start to study new ways of thinking and perspective. I'm using skills I learned in my degree constantly‚Äîmy dad was right, as he so often is.You will hear a lot of people tell you that an English major is a degree with limited usefulness. F*ck 'em. Kuye ka medhak ban gaye the!(felt like a frog in a well). The worst thing above all, classes did start offline but all minor and major exams were conducted online, which I feel was useless.Lesson 8The ‚Äòonly good thing‚Äô or ‚Äúbenefit‚Äù of joining Aakash that I felt was the test series at the endThere was one thing that I pledged this year, and that was, I wouldn‚Äôt touch the OMR until it was the last 20 minutes of paper, as I‚Äôd done this mistake in NEET 2020I had solved a total of 61 test papers in the last 40 days (55 coaching papers, allen & aakash combined, and 6 past year papers) and near aboutI had a different approach in solving the OMR. I would solve the paper completely and then section-wise, I would put a DOT on responses which I had to darken. In such a way, if I made a mistake, then only a dot would be there on OMR, not a dark bubble as that would be game over. So, after putting a DOT on every answer on OMR, I would bubble all OMRs in one go. I told him that I‚Äôve made this mistake last year and I‚Äôm not going to repeat that mistake.Anyways, I entered the exam room at around 1:35. Was getting comfortable, everything was good. The clock showed 1:55. We asked them to give the paper so that we could fill Name etc on OMR, as in previous years we were given paper 10‚Äì15 min prior to the exam starting time. Bell rang at 1:55, But these dipshit invigilators gave paper at 2:00. Khud ko samjhaye, it‚Äôs fine..don‚Äôt panic. And then everything happened at once, filling OMR, signature on the Attendance sheet, signature on OMR, cross-checking of OMR sheet, it took 15 mins.I started solving, Biology was going smooth AF. Completed biology till 2:40. Took around 25 min, which was good according to all the mock tests. Started with Chemistry, felt the paper is good(my chemistry was average, especially inorganic), solved 2‚Äì3 questions, but what my father said bugged me continuously, so I came back to OMR and I filled Botany with extreme cautiousness as I never filled OMR this way, this wasn‚Äôt my game-plan. It took me nearly 5 mins to complete the Botany section OMR and in the Zoology section, I had put dots on my responses by didn‚Äôt darken it, thinking I have plenty of time right now, and my subconscious told me not to try anything new. So, I came back to solving chemistry with only my Botany OMR filled.Solved Chemistry till 3:30. Felt like losing confidence but then, it was time for my favorite subject now, physics.When I started solving physics, I felt that the paper was really good. Those who have ‚Äúreally studied‚Äù the topic, only they would be able to solve the paper. Nobody protested that there‚Äôs 5 min left. 12 students in class and not one of them raised their voice. These idiots were sitting ideally. The ma‚Äôam there, called security. 1 teacher and 2 people came who were just outside my class came in, this happened in a matter of seconds. They all started manhandling me,I knew it has been messed up, everything is over now.Came out of the center, my brother and Aakash faculty were there, waiting.Words weren‚Äôt coming out of my mouth, I was about to explode in tears, but I couldn‚Äôt. I felt my heart pumping very fast. I didn‚Äôt know what was happening, didn‚Äôt know if this really had happened. Teachers came to me, asked how my paper went. They said ‚ÄúStay calm Sudhanshu, what is done is done, it‚Äôs fine, the paper was tough, cutoff would be around 570‚Äì580, and seeing my physics they said you really have done well. Yes, I DID.So, when I say, everything is not going to happen as you plan, I mean it. Your ‚Äúplans‚Äù would laugh at your face if they aren‚Äôt backed up with proper hard work.
